author: Nick Green
title: U.S. Soccer fails to give USMNT boss Jurgen Klinsmann das boot despite losing team, fans and big games
text:
Any doubts U.S. men’s national team coach Jurgen Klinsmann is held to a different standard than predecessor Bob Bradley were dispelled this week in the wake of two defeats in four days to CONCACAF opposition.
Bradley was bounced by U.S. Soccer after losing 4-2 to Mexico in the 2011 Gold Cup final, a game the U.S. had led 2-0 at one stage.
Klinsmann lost in similarly disastrous fashion to Mexico in Pasadena with his team being completely dominated by a far superior opponent that nonetheless needed a world-class winning goal in second-half stoppage time to finish off the Americans, who never looked as close to winning as the score line suggested.
The difference between the two games — absolutely none — except that Klinsmann wasn’t fired in the aftermath and promptly went on to lead the U.S. to another defeat on Tuesday at the hands of Costa Rica .
The results have the men’s national team at its lowest ebb in years, right before going out and playing two World Cup qualifiers next month against St. Vincent and the Grenadines and Trinidad & Tobago four days later.
Klinsmann’s grand plan to win the Gold Cup this summer, followed by qualification to the 2017 Confederations Cup, that’s seen as a springboard to a successful 2018 World Cup campaign the following year, is in ruins.
Poke through the rubble in search of answers and one is far more likely to unearth questions:
•Has the USMNT progressed during Klinsmann’s four years in charge?
•Is there a successful system in place that includes dangerous strikers, midfield creativity and defensive resolve?
•Are there a core of players who have formed the foundation of a successful team to see the U.S. through the 2018 World Cup?
In every case the answer has to be no.
Klinsmann demanded total control over every level of the U.S. men’s soccer program, yet the U-23 team is in danger of failing to qualify for the Olympics (again).
Poor choices appear to have dogged Klinsmann at every step, yet U.S. Soccer boss Sunil Gulati remains resolutely in his corner, the Ivy League economics professor apparently unwilling to cut his losses and dissolve his investment in a rapidly diminishing portfolio to put in language he understands.
Players, too, seem unwilling to take risks for Klinsmann, perhaps unsurprisingly for a coach who has shown a proclivity for throwing his players under a bus. The latest was right back Fabian Johnson, who was far more concerned about returning to his club team uninjured than playing his heart out for coach and country and sent packing from the U.S. squad before the Costa Rica game.
Advertisement
Saturday’s game cried out for a player of Landon Donovan’s vision and influence in midfield, yet neither Michael Bradley or Kyle Beckerman looked remotely capable of fulfilling the role against Mexico.
Gulati will surely point out that the offensively unimpressive Mexico only just beat the U.S. at the Rose Bowl, but the Americans were frankly lucky El Tri’s territorial dominance did not result in more goals.
So let’s recap: Bradley was fired after blowing a two-goal lead in a big game against the USMNT arch rivals, but Klinsmann won’t be despite the Americans never looking like they were capable of victory for the vast majority of what was a dreadfully dull game until the last few minutes?
Bradley was fired despite his record, including a creditable second in the 2011 Confederations Cup, a tournament Klinsmann has never qualified for.
Double standard?
Undoubtedly.
